documents.summary: This circular extends the timeline for implementing the SEBI circular regarding margin obligations to be given by way of pledge/re-pledge in the Depository System. The extension is granted based on requests from depositories for more time to complete system developments and testing, ensuring a smooth transition for market participants and investors. The new effective date is October 10, 2025.

key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This extension provides additional time for depositories, stock exchanges, clearing corporations, and their members/participants to prepare their systems and procedures for compliance with the margin pledge/re-pledge requirements.

documents.summary: This circular allows Investment Advisers (IAs) and Research Analysts (RAs) to use liquid mutual funds and overnight mutual funds, as an alternative to bank deposits, for compliance with deposit requirements as specified under IA Regulations and RA Regulations. The circular mandates that such deposits be marked as lien in favor of IAASB or RAASB and sets a compliance deadline of September 30, 2025.

key_clauses.clause_title: Deposit Requirement for Investment Advisers and Research Analysts
key_clauses.clause_content: Investment Advisers (IAs) and Research Analysts (RAs) are required to maintain a deposit as specified by SEBI from time to time, previously required to be maintained with a scheduled bank marked as lien in favor of Investment Adviser Administration and Supervisory body (IAASB) or Research Analyst Administration and Supervisory body (RAASB).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause mandates that IAs and RAs must maintain a deposit to ensure financial stability and investor protection.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: IAs and RAs can now maintain the deposit in the form of units of liquid mutual fund or an overnight mutual fund or as a deposit maintained with a scheduled bank. Such deposit shall be marked as lien in favor of IAASB or RAASB, as the case may be.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause provides IAs and RAs with more flexibility in meeting the deposit requirement by allowing them to use liquid and overnight mutual funds.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: IAs and RAs shall comply with the deposit requirements latest by September 30, 2025.

key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause places the responsibility on IAASB/RAASB to ensure that the new regulations are implemented effectively and that IAs/RAs are informed of the changes.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: The provisions of this circular shall come into effect from the date of issuance of this circular.

documents.summary: This circular reviews the framework for conversion of Private Listed InvIT into Public InvIT as outlined in Chapter 14 of the Master Circular for Infrastructure Investment Trusts (InvITs) dated May 15, 2024. It streamlines requirements for minimum unitholding by sponsors and sponsor groups and aligns the procedure and disclosure requirements for public offers with those applicable for follow-on offers.

key_clauses.clause_title: Minimum Unitholding Requirement for Sponsor(s) and Sponsor Group(s)
key_clauses.clause_content: The sponsor(s) and sponsor group(s) shall comply with the minimum unitholding requirement specified in Regulation 12(3) and 12(3A) of the InvIT Regulations, as applicable, at all times.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures that sponsors and sponsor groups maintain a minimum level of investment in the InvIT, aligning their interests with those of public unitholders.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Non-compliance would attract penalties as per InvIT Regulations.

key_clauses.clause_title: Lock-in on Units Held by Sponsor(s) and Sponsor Group(s)
key_clauses.clause_content: The lock-in on units held by the sponsor(s) and sponsor group(s) to comply with the minimum unitholding requirement mentioned in paragraph 14.6.1 shall be as specified in Regulation 12(5) of the InvIT Regulations.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Restricts the ability of sponsors and sponsor groups to sell their units for a specified period, further aligning their interests with long-term performance of the InvIT.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Violation of lock-in provisions would attract penalties as per InvIT Regulations.

key_clauses.clause_title: Alignment of Public Offer Procedure with Follow-on Offer
key_clauses.clause_content: The procedure and disclosure requirements for public offer of units to convert a private listed InvIT into a public InvIT are aligned with the procedure and disclosure requirements applicable for follow-on offer. Specifically, references to 'initial' offer are replaced with 'follow-on' offer, and the InvIT must comply with requirements for follow-on offers prescribed under InvIT Regulations and circulars issued thereunder.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Simplifies the conversion process by leveraging existing regulations and procedures for follow-on offers, reducing compliance burden and potential ambiguities.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Non-compliance with follow-on offer requirements would attract penalties as per InvIT Regulations.

key_clauses.clause_content: Details of distributions made by the InvIT, as applicable for a follow-on offer, must be disclosed.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures transparency and provides investors with information about the InvIT's distribution history.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to disclose distribution details would attract penalties as per InvIT Regulations.

documents.summary: This circular introduces a policy for joint annual inspections by Market Infrastructure Institutions (MIIs) to ease the burden on intermediaries and improve supervision effectiveness. It outlines an information-sharing mechanism among MIIs, revises the criteria for selecting entities for annual inspection, and designates a 'Lead MII' to initiate enforcement actions.

key_clauses.clause_content: Entities selected for annual inspections shall be inspected jointly by all exchanges along with their depository participant (DP) operations (if broker is also registered as DP) and clearing activity (if the broker is undertaking clearing for other brokers). DP operations and clearing activity undertaken by entities shall be inspected by Depositories and Clearing Corporations, respectively. This will ensure that entities selected by MIIs for their annual inspection shall be inspected jointly by all MIIs at one time.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Reduces the frequency of inspections for brokers/DPs, minimizing disruption to their operations and optimizing resource utilization for both MIIs and intermediaries.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this section, but non-compliance with inspection findings may lead to enforcement actions.

key_clauses.clause_content: MIIs shall establish an information sharing mechanism with one another for sharing of inspection observations of entities who hold multiple registrations with MIIs.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Enhances the effectiveness of supervision by providing MIIs with a comprehensive view of an entity's operations across different segments and exchanges.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified, but failure to share information may hinder effective supervision and lead to regulatory scrutiny.

key_clauses.clause_content:
The criteria for annual inspection are revised as follows:
a. Top 25 entities paying high and recurring penalties for non-reporting or short reporting of margin/Client Code modification/CTCL mismatch fines or any other similar high risk compliance issue - shall be inspected irrespective of when they were last inspected.
b. Top 25 entities in terms of investor complaints and arbitration cases filed by investors, as percentage of number of active clients shall be inspected irrespective of the fact of when they were last inspected.
c. Top 25 entities based on ‘High risk score’ under Risk Based Supervision.
Entities that do not fall under any of the above categories shall be inspected by the MIIs at least once in three years.
However, entities inspected in preceding two years by any of the MII’s/SEBI and/or entities that have not executed a single trade during last two financial years may not be considered for inspection under the above criteria.
Irrespective of the above, inspections of Professional Clearing Members shall be conducted jointly by Clearing Corporations once in two years.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Focuses inspection efforts on entities posing higher risks, such as those with frequent penalties, high investor complaints, or high-risk scores. Introduces a minimum inspection frequency for other entities.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified, but failure to comply with inspection requirements may lead to enforcement actions.

key_clauses.clause_content: Notwithstanding the above, MIIs shall have the prerogative to carry out special purpose/limited inspections based on any triggers like patterns found during investor complaint resolution/Arbitration, complaints on specific malpractices of a broker or references from various authorities. The inspection shall be irrespective of the fact of when the last inspection was carried out.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Allows MIIs to conduct targeted inspections based on specific concerns or triggers, ensuring timely intervention and addressing potential malpractices.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified, but non-compliance with inspection findings may lead to enforcement actions.

key_clauses.clause_content: MIIs are advised to frame a joint Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) by November 01, 2025 for detailed specifications of inspection criteria, information sharing mechanism and designating one MII as a ‘Lead MII’, which will initiate enforcement action for such inspections.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures consistency and clarity in the inspection process, information sharing, and enforcement actions across different MIIs.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified, but failure to establish a joint SOP may lead to regulatory scrutiny.

key_clauses.clause_content: MIIs are advised to continuously review the policy of annual inspection and revise, as and when required, in consultation with SEBI.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures that the annual inspection policy remains relevant and effective in addressing evolving market dynamics and regulatory requirements.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: Qualified Stock Brokers (QSBs) shall continue to be governed by SEBI circular on ‘Enhanced obligations and responsibilities on QSBs’ dated February 06, 2023 and any changes issued from time to time by SEBI/exchanges.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies that the existing regulations for QSBs remain in effect and are not superseded by this circular.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Non-compliance with the SEBI circular on ‘Enhanced obligations and responsibilities on QSBs’ will attract penalties as specified in that circular.

key_clauses.clause_title: Rescission and Amendment of Previous Circulars
key_clauses.clause_content: With the issuance of this circular, SEBI Circular CIR/HO/MIRSD/MIRSD2/CIR/P/2017/73 dated June 30, 2017 stands rescinded and para 14 of Master Circular for Stock Brokers dated June 17, 2025 stands amended as per this circular.

documents.summary: This circular modifies the handling of review, appeal, or waiver requests for penalties imposed by Member Committees (MC) of Market Infrastructure Institutions (MIIs). It mandates that requests against actions by Internal Committees or pre-approved policy actions are placed before the MC, while requests against MC actions are handled by a mechanism set up by the Governing Board with Public Interest Directors and/or Independent External Professionals. The circular is effective from the 45th day of its issuance.

key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause establishes the foundation for the authority and responsibilities of the Statutory Committees within MIIs, ensuring they operate within a defined framework.

documents.summary: This circular mandates compliance with the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016, and its rules by all SEBI-regulated entities (REs). It aims to ensure digital accessibility for persons with disabilities on all digital platforms of REs, requiring them to adhere to specific accessibility standards and guidelines, conduct audits, and remediate any identified issues within specified timelines.

key_clauses.clause_content: All Regulated Entities (REs) must ensure their Digital Platforms are compliant with the provisions of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016 (“RPwD Act, 2016”) and corresponding rules, specifically Section 40 (Accessibility), Section 42 (Access to information and communication technology), Section 46 (Time limit for accessibility by service providers), and Rule 15(1)(c) of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Rules, 2017 (Rules for Accessibility).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must modify their digital platforms to ensure accessibility for persons with disabilities, including necessary features and functionalities.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in the circular, but non-compliance with the RPwD Act, 2016, may attract penalties under that Act.

key_clauses.clause_content: REs must adhere to accessibility standards and guidelines, including Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (“WCAG”) 2.1 or latest version, Accessibility guidelines as described in the latest version of Guidelines for Indian Government Websites (“GIGW”), IS 17802: Indian Standards on Accessibility Requirements for Information and Communication Technology (“ICT”) Products and Services, and Provisions of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016 and corresponding rules for digital accessibility mentioned in this Circular.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must ensure their digital platforms meet specific technical standards for accessibility.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in the circular, but non-compliance may attract penalties under the RPwD Act, 2016.

key_clauses.clause_content: Compliance with the circular shall be reviewed and approved by the Managing Director or the Managing Partner or the Proprietor of the REs. REs shall designate a senior officer as the Nodal Officer for digital accessibility compliance. In the absence of an officially designated Nodal Officer, the Compliance Officer or the Proprietor shall be deemed to be the Nodal Officer.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must establish internal oversight and accountability for digital accessibility compliance.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in the circular, but failure to designate a Nodal Officer may be considered non-compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: A grievance redressal mechanism specific to accessibility issues shall be institutionalized within the REs. Channels such as email, helpline, and web forms must be user-friendly for PwDs. The system must include provisions for escalation to senior officers.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must establish a dedicated system for addressing accessibility-related complaints.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in the circular, but failure to establish a grievance redressal mechanism may be considered non-compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: The Digital Platforms of the REs shall include features such as Indian Sign Language (ISL) videos, closed captioning, descriptive audio, and alternate text for images. All circulars, notices, and investor documents published on the Digital Platforms of the RE’s (website, mobile application, etc.) in PDF or other formats must follow accessible document standards—such as tagged PDFs, logical reading order, proper use of headings, and alt text.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must implement specific accessibility features on their digital platforms and ensure documents are accessible.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in the circular, but failure to implement these features may be considered non-compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: Training modules that give detailed understanding on digital accessibility (website, mobile application, etc.) shall be part of all internal training programs for staff and third-party service providers who are developing and publishing content for dissemination via Digital Platforms. The Digital Platform shall be “accessible by design”. Trainings should emphasize on design wise digital accessibility. The trainings should cover behavioural training, assistive tools, and inclusive experience for normal as well as differently abled users.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must train their staff and service providers on digital accessibility.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in the circular, but failure to provide adequate training may be considered non-compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: All REs shall ensure that digital KYC, e-KYC, and video KYC processes include alternatives to accommodate differently abled users/clients. For example, human-assisted video KYC, allowing scanned document uploads, or voice-assisted KYC for visually impaired users. KYC and client registration forms shall include a mandatory field to indicate disability status and options to select specific provisions such as helpdesk call back for assistance. Any application of a client with disability shall be rejected by the REs only after a review by a designated human officer and the said officer shall be empowered to override automated rejections and approve applications on a case by case basis, thereby ensuring equitable access to services of the REs for persons with disabilities.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must adapt their KYC and registration processes to accommodate persons with disabilities.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in the circular, but failure to provide accessible KYC processes may be considered non-compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: All REs shall initiate a comprehensive accessibility audit of their digital platforms including websites, mobile apps, portals through International Association of Accessibility Professionals (“IAAP”). The audit shall follow the latest WCAG, GIGW guidelines and RPwD Act and sules made thereunder and also SEBI from time to time. The said accessibility audit shall include usability testing by persons with disabilities. Based on the audit findings, REs shall prepare and implement a plan for remediation of audit observations. Existing digital platforms must be upgraded to meet accessibility standards within the transition timeline. All REs shall conduct annual accessibility audits of their digital platforms including websites, mobile apps, portals through IAAP certified accessibility professionals and reports shall be submitted as per the mechanism specified in direction 1.4 in Section 1 of this Annexure.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must conduct accessibility audits and remediate any identified issues.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in the circular, but failure to conduct audits or remediate issues may be considered non-compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: All newly developed/procured digital solutions shall conform to latest WCAG, IS17802, GIGW guidelines and the provisions of the RPwD Act, 2016 and rules made thereunder. In case of Software as a Service (“SaaS”)/ customised SaaS products, vendors must seek conformance with the accessibility guidelines by conducting audit of their product/service in accordance to WCAG 2.1 (or latest) accessibility guidelines. The responsibility to ensure the accessibility of a Digital Platform shall lie with the REs. Accessibility requirements shall be part of all Request for Proposals (“RFPs”) and procurement contracts of the REs and evaluation criteria of the REs shall assign due weightage to accessibility readiness.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must ensure that all new digital solutions are accessible and that accessibility is considered in procurement processes.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in the circular, but failure to ensure accessibility in procurement may be considered non-compliance.

documents.summary: This circular clarifies the monitoring of the Minimum Investment Threshold for Specialized Investment Funds (SIFs). It outlines the procedure to be followed in case of a breach, including freezing of units, providing notice to investors, and automatic redemption if the threshold is not met within the stipulated timeframe.

key_clauses.clause_content: The Asset Management Company shall monitor compliance with the Minimum Investment Threshold on a daily basis and ensure that there are no active breaches. The AMC shall ensure that the investor’s total investment value does not fall below the Minimum Investment Threshold due to redemption transactions initiated by the investor.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: AMCs are required to actively monitor and prevent breaches of the minimum investment threshold by investors in SIFs.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but non-compliance could lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_title: Freezing of Units and Notice to Investor
key_clauses.clause_content: In case of any active breach of the Minimum Investment Threshold by an investor, all units of such investor held across investment strategies of the concerned SIF shall be frozen for debit, and a notice of 30 calendar days shall be given to such investor to rebalance the investments in order to comply with the Minimum Investment Threshold.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Investors breaching the minimum threshold will have their units frozen and will be given a 30-day notice to rectify the breach.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Automatic redemption of frozen units if the breach is not rectified within 30 days.

key_clauses.clause_content: In case investor rebalances his/her investments in SIF within the notice period of 30 calendar days, the units of SIF of such investor shall be unfreezed, and no further action shall be taken with regard to compliance with Minimum Investment Threshold.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Provides a mechanism for investors to rectify the breach and have their units unfrozen.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: None, if the investor complies within the stipulated timeframe.

key_clauses.clause_content: In case the investor fails to rebalance the investments within the aforesaid 30 calendar day period, the frozen units shall be automatically redeemed by the AMC, at the applicable Net Asset Value of the next immediate business day after the 30th calendar day of the notice period.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: AMCs are required to automatically redeem the units of investors who fail to meet the minimum investment threshold after the notice period.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but failure to redeem could lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: For the purpose of SIF, the ‘Active Breach’ shall mean fall in the aggregate value of an investor’s total investment across all investment strategies of SIF, below the Minimum Investment Threshold of INR 10 lakh, on account of any transactions (i.e. redemption, transfer, sale etc.) initiated by the investor.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines the specific circumstances that constitute an active breach of the minimum investment threshold.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Triggers the freezing of units and the notice period as described above.

documents.summary: This SEBI circular provides clarifications on regulatory provisions for Research Analysts (RAs) through a set of Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs). It addresses various aspects of RA Regulations, including registration requirements, exemptions, compliance obligations, and the interplay between research and distribution activities, and provides some relaxations for institutional investors.

key_clauses.clause_title: NISM Certification for Persons Associated with Research Services
key_clauses.clause_content: Persons associated with research services shall obtain the relevant certification from NISM as specified by SEBI within one year from the date of this circular or within the timeline as may be specified by SEBI. This clarifies the scope of personnel requiring certification, excluding those with no client contact or connection to research services.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Impacts research entities by requiring them to ensure that personnel associated with research services obtain NISM certification. It also clarifies which personnel are considered 'associated with research services'.
key_clauses.effective_date: July 23, 2026 (one year from the date of the circular)
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this section, but failure to comply with certification requirements may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_title: Consent on Terms and Conditions for Institutional Investors/QIBs
key_clauses.clause_content: Consent by signature on the terms and conditions including most important terms and conditions (MITC) shall not be mandatory for the clients who are institutional investors or qualified institutional buyers. However, RAs/research entities are required to disclose the terms and conditions of research services including MITC to these clients.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Eases compliance for RAs by removing the mandatory consent requirement for institutional investors/QIBs, while still requiring disclosure of terms and conditions.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified, but failure to disclose terms and conditions may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: The personnel engaged in clerical activities/marketing activities, back office assistance, support services, etc., in relation to publication and/or distribution of research report are not covered under the definition of research analysts. These personnel are also not considered as persons associated with research services if – (i) these personnel while performing these activities do not have client contact, or (ii) these activities have no connection with the research services provided as a RA.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies the scope of who is considered a research analyst and associated with research services, providing clarity for compliance purposes.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified.

key_clauses.clause_content: "Research report” does not include the following communications: - i. comments on general trends in the securities market; ii. discussions on the broad-based indices; iii. commentaries on economic, political or market conditions; iv. periodic reports or other communications prepared for unit holders of Mutual Fund or Alternative Investment Fund or clients of Portfolio Managers and Investment Advisers; v. internal communications that are not given to current or prospective clients; vi. communications that constitute offer documents or prospectus that are circulated as per regulations made by SEBI; vii. statistical summaries of financial data of the companies; viii. technical analyses relating to the demand and supply in a sector or the index; ix. any other communication which SEBI may specify from time to time.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Narrows the scope of what constitutes a research report, reducing the compliance burden for certain communications.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified.

key_clauses.clause_content: Research services provided under RA Regulations are specific to the securities under purview of SEBI and are agnostic to the methodology used to provide research services. Providing research services (including buy/sell/hold recommendation) on a security or securities based on any methodology (including the technical analysis) is not exempted from the purview of the RA Regulations. However, technical analyses relating to the demand and supply for a particular sector or index is exempted from the purview of RA Regulations.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies that technical analysis-based research services are covered under RA Regulations, except for analyses related to sector or index demand and supply.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified.

key_clauses.clause_content: SEBI registered Stock Brokers, Merchant Bankers and other intermediaries except those who are exempted from making application for registration under RA Regulations are required to make application for grant of registration under RA Regulations, if they are engaged in issuance of research reports or research analyses. Such intermediaries are covered under the definition of ‘research entity’.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Reinforces the registration requirement for intermediaries engaged in research activities.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Acting as a research analyst or research entity without registration may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: Investment Advisers, Credit Rating Agencies, Asset Management Companies and Fund Managers (i.e. Fund Managers of a mutual fund or alternative investment fund or venture capital fund or portfolio manager) are not required to be registered under RA Regulations. However, in case such intermediaries issue/circulate/distribute research reports to public or general investors and/or if they or their directors or employees make public appearance, they shall be required to comply with Chapter III of the RA Regulations.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Specifies exemptions from RA registration for certain intermediaries, with a condition for compliance with Chapter III of RA Regulations if they issue research reports to the public or make public appearances.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to comply with Chapter III of RA Regulations may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: Yes. Proxy Advisers are required to obtain registration from SEBI under RA Regulations. All the provisions of Chapter II, III, IV, V and VI of RA Regulations shall apply mutatis mutandis to the proxy adviser. The proxy adviser shall be required to additionally disclose the following: i. the extent of research involved in a particular recommendation and the extent and/or effectiveness of its controls and procedures in ensuring the accuracy of issuer data; ii. policies and procedures for interacting with issuers, informing issuers about the recommendation and review of recommendations. Proxy adviser is required to maintain the record of his voting recommendations and furnish the same to SEBI on request.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Mandates registration for proxy advisors and outlines additional disclosure requirements.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Acting as a proxy advisor without registration may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: Application fees must be paid along with application form for grant of registration. The details of the applicable fees to be paid to SEBI are as below: S. Category Application Registration Renewal Fee No. Fee Fee (for the (for first five years subsequent of registration) five years) 1 Individual and Rs. 2,000 Rs. 3,000 Rs. 1,000 Partnership Firms 2 Proxy Advisers Rs. 2,000 Rs. 3,000 Rs. 1,000 3 Body Corporate Rs. 20,000 Rs.30,000 Rs. 5,000 including Limited Liability Partnership Further, the RAs are required to be enlisted with the RAASB and to pay administrative fees as specified by RAASB.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Specifies the application, registration, and renewal fees for different categories of research analysts.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Non-payment of fees may lead to rejection of application or cancellation of registration.

key_clauses.clause_content: There is no capital adequacy requirement applicable to an RA. However, an RA is required to maintain a deposit with RAASB in accordance with their number of clients in the manner specified by SEBI. The applicable deposit requirements are as under: No. of clients Deposit Up to 150 clients ₹ 1 lakh 151 to 300 clients ₹ 2 lakhs 301 to 1,000 clients ₹ 5 lakhs 1,001 and above clients ₹ 10 lakhs
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Introduces a deposit requirement with RAASB based on the number of clients.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to maintain the required deposit may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: Independent research analysts, part-time research analysts, individuals employed as research analyst or their associates shall not deal or trade any securities that the research analyst recommends or follows within 30 days before and 5 days after the publication of a research report on the subject company. Independent research analysts, part-time research analysts, individuals employed as research analyst or their associates shall not deal or trade directly or indirectly in securities that he reviews in a manner contrary to his given recommendation. Independent research analysts, part-time research analysts, individuals employed as research analyst or their associates shall not purchase or receive securities of the issuer before the issuer's initial public offering, if the issuer is principally engaged in the same types of business as companies that the research analyst follows or recommends. The aforesaid trading restrictions under regulation 16 of RA Regulations are also applicable in respect of research entities where the entity has not segregated its research activities from all other activities and maintained an arms-length relationship between such activities.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Imposes trading restrictions on research analysts and their associates to prevent conflicts of interest.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Violation of trading restrictions may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: A non-individual research analyst or research entity is required to appoint a compliance officer who shall be responsible for monitoring the compliance in respect of the requirements of the Act, RA regulations and circulars issued by SEBI. A non-individual research analyst may appoint an independent professional who is a member of ICAI or ICSI or ICMAI or member of any other professional body as may be specified by the SEBI, provided such a professional holds a relevant certification from NISM, as may be specified by the SEBI.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Mandates the appointment of a compliance officer for non-individual research analysts or research entities.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to appoint a compliance officer may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: In case of intermediaries such as brokers or merchant bankers who provide research services as value added services to their clients, the brokerage/merchant banking charges/ tariff consideration include the consideration for the research services though it may not be separately identified/attributed to the research services. Thus, research services provided to these clients are considered as research services ‘for consideration’ under RA Regulations even though no separate fee for research services is received by these intermediaries directly from the clients.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies that research services provided as value-added services are considered 'for consideration' even if no separate fee is charged.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified.

key_clauses.clause_title: Segregation of Research and Distribution Activities
key_clauses.clause_content: RA/research entity can provide distribution services on products/securities provided they are not providing research services on such products/securities being distributed and are providing such distribution services through separately identifiable department or division or business unit within the same entity or through a separate entity on an arms’ length basis. Client level segregation of research and distribution services is not required if RA/research entity distributes mutual funds/PMS schemes/AIF products but provides research services only on individual stocks and is not providing research services on mutual funds/PMS schemes/AIF products. e.g. If a RA distributes 'Mutual Fund Scheme A' at family or group level, it cannot provide research services on 'Mutual Fund Scheme A' and vice versa at family/group level. The RA/research entity is required to maintain client level segregation at family/group level in case it is engaged in providing research services on mutual funds and is also engaged in distribution of mutual funds. RA/research entity may carry out distribution of other products (such as banking products) not under purview of SEBI to their clients at family/group level. Any grievances related to such products shall not come under purview of SEBI.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies the rules regarding segregation of research and distribution activities, allowing distribution of different products than those being researched under certain conditions.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Violation of segregation rules may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: As per the explanation to regulation 2(ne) of the RA regulations, all client and public facing persons such as analysts, sales staff, service relationship managers, client relationship managers, etc., by whatever name called, shall be deemed to be persons associated with research services, but shall not include persons who discharge clerical or office administrative functions if where there is no connection with research services and they have no client contact. Ii is clarified that the aforesaid personnel are not considered as persons associated with research services if – (i) these personnel while performing activities/services do not have client contact, or (ii) these activities/services have no connection with the research services provided as a RA. It shall not be mandatory for such persons to obtain the NISM certification. Persons associated with research services shall obtain the relevant certification from NISM as specified by SEBI within one year from the date of this circular or within the timeline as may be specified by SEBI.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies the NISM certification requirements for client-facing staff, excluding those with no client contact or connection to research services.
key_clauses.effective_date: July 23, 2026 (one year from the date of the circular)
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to ensure NISM certification for relevant staff may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_title: Compliance Requirements for Non-Fee Paying Clients
key_clauses.clause_content: RAs/research entities are required to follow the KYC procedure for clients paying fees directly for research services. The requirement of maintenance of records of interactions with clients such as call recordings, emails, etc. is applicable for fee-paying as well as non-fee paying clients whereas non-fee paying clients are the clients receiving research services as a value added service along with other services availed from the research entity or any other entity at family/group level on payable basis. For the purpose of abundant clarity, it is to be stated that call recording is not required if the interaction with client is made through means such as email, etc. for which digital footprint is available. The purpose of the records of the client interaction is to document the interaction to cater to potential client grievances related to research services provided by the research analyst/ research entity. Access to an effective grievance redressal mechanism is a basic right of every investor irrespective of the nature of the investors i.e. individual/ HUF/ institutions etc. Hence, RAs/research entities shall ensure compliance with the provision for maintenance of records of interactions even in case of their clients who are institutional investors or QIBs.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies KYC and record-keeping requirements for non-fee paying clients.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to comply with KYC and record-keeping requirements may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: The term ‘consideration’ under RA regulation is defined as any form of economic benefit including non-cash benefit, received or receivable, directly or indirectly, in any form whether from client or otherwise for providing research services. Non-fee paying clients are the clients receiving research services as a value added service along with other services availed from the research entity or any other entity at family/group level on payable basis. This is also highlighted in response to FAQ No. 29 above where ‘consideration’ is received indirectly by research entity. Thus, the number of clients of RA/research entity shall mean total of fee-paying clients and non-fee paying clients of RA/research entity. RA/research entity is required to report this number of clients (fee-paying and non-fee paying clients) in periodic reporting format and shall also form basis for determining the requisite deposit amount applicable to the RA/research entity. The research entity is required to ensure the compliance with the requirement of disclosure of terms and conditions of research services to all such clients and to take their consent thereupon, except for clients who are institutional investors/QIBs for whom mere disclosure shall suffice and there shall be no requirement of seeking their consent to terms and conditions.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies that non-fee paying clients are considered clients for reporting and deposit purposes.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Inaccurate reporting of client numbers may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: As per the existing provisions, exemption on compliance with client level segregation of research services and distribution activities is given to only entities providing research services exclusively to institutional clients if the client signs a standard waiver. Institutional clients/QIBs are sophisticated investors who have necessary skills, knowledge and means to protect their interests and take informed decisions. Accordingly, in exercise of power under Regulation 33 of RA Regulations and for ease of doing business, it is clarified that even in cases where research service is not exclusively provided to institutional clients/QIBs, all research analysts/entities are exempted from ‘client level segregation of research and distribution activities’ for their institutional clients/QIBs if such a client provides a standard waiver. Client may also provide such standard waiver through e-mail or any other electronically verifiable mode. However, such exemption shall not be applicable in case of clients other than institutional clients/QIBs.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Expands the exemption from client-level segregation to all research analysts/entities for their institutional clients/QIBs if a standard waiver is provided.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to obtain a waiver from institutional clients/QIBs may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: Research analyst or research entity are required to maintain the rationale for arriving at research recommendations. They are required to have adequate documentary basis, supported by research, for preparing a research report and shall ensure that recommendations in the research report are corroborated by relevant data and analysis forming the basis for such research service.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Reinforces the requirement to maintain rationale and documentary basis for research recommendations.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to maintain adequate rationale and documentation may lead to regulatory action by SEBI.

documents.summary: This SEBI circular announces a special window for re-lodgement of transfer requests for physical shares that were lodged before April 1, 2019, and rejected due to deficiencies. The window will be open for six months, from July 7, 2025, to January 6, 2026, and all re-lodged shares must be issued in demat mode.

key_clauses.clause_content: Transfer of securities in physical mode was discontinued with effect from April 01, 2019. Subsequently, it was clarified that transfer deeds lodged prior to deadline of April 01, 2019 and rejected/returned due to deficiency in the documents may be re-lodged with requisite documents. It was further decided to fix March 31, 2021 as the cut-off date for re-lodgement of transfer deeds.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause establishes the initial timeline for physical share transfers and the subsequent re-lodgement deadline, setting the stage for the special window.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Special Window for Re-lodgement of Transfer Deeds
key_clauses.clause_content: In order to facilitate ease of investing for investors and to secure the rights of investors in the securities which were purchased by them, it has been decided to open a special window only for re-lodgement of transfer deeds, which were lodged prior to the deadline of April 01, 2019 and rejected/returned/not attended to due to deficiency in the documents/process/or otherwise, for a period of six months from July 07, 2025 till January 06, 2026.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause allows investors who missed the previous deadline to re-lodge their transfer deeds, providing them with another opportunity to transfer their shares.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: During this period, the securities that are re-lodged for transfer (including those requests that are pending with the listed company / RTA, as on date) shall be issued only in demat mode. Due process shall be followed for such transfer-cum-demat requests.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause mandates that all securities re-lodged during the special window must be issued in dematerialized form, promoting dematerialization of securities.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: Listed companies, RTAs and Stock Exchanges shall publicize the opening of this special window through various media including print and social media, on a bi-monthly basis during the six-month period.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause requires listed companies, RTAs, and Stock Exchanges to actively inform investors about the special window, ensuring maximum participation.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: RTAs/listed companies shall have focussed teams to attend to such requests.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause mandates RTAs and listed companies to establish dedicated teams to handle the re-lodgement requests efficiently.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: RTAs/listed companies shall provide reports on: 7.1 publicity; and 7.2 shares re-lodged for transfer cum demat in the format specified by SEBI (provided at Annexure-A) on monthly basis.

documents.summary: This circular pertains to the Industry Standards on "Minimum information to be provided to the Audit Committee and Shareholders for approval of Related Party Transactions (RPT)". It modifies Section III-B of the Master Circular dated November 11, 2024, by substituting paragraphs under Part A and Part B with references to the Industry Standards. The circular mandates listed entities to follow the revised RPT Industry Standards and supersedes previous circulars on the same subject.

key_clauses.clause_title: Modification of Master Circular - Information to Audit Committee
key_clauses.clause_content: Paragraph 4 under Part A of Section III-B of the Master Circular shall stand substituted by the following paragraph: “The listed entity shall provide the audit committee with the information as specified in the Industry Standards on “Minimum information to be provided to the Audit Committee and Shareholders for approval of Related Party Transactions”, while placing any proposal for review and approval of an RPT.”
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Listed entities must now provide the audit committee with the information specified in the RPT Industry Standards when seeking approval for RPTs.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Modification of Master Circular - Information to Shareholders
key_clauses.clause_content: Paragraph 6 under Part B of Section III-B of the Master Circular shall stand substituted by the following paragraph: “The notice being sent to the shareholders seeking approval for any RPT shall, in addition to the requirements under the Companies Act, 2013, include the information as part of the explanatory statement as specified in the Industry Standards on “Minimum information to be provided to the Audit Committee and Shareholders for approval of Related Party Transactions.”
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Listed entities must include the information specified in the RPT Industry Standards as part of the explanatory statement in the notice sent to shareholders seeking approval for RPTs, in addition to the requirements under the Companies Act, 2013.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: The listed entities, from the effective date of this Circular, shall follow the aforesaid RPT Industry Standards to ensure compliance with Part A and Part B of Section III-B of the Master Circular read with Regulation 23(2), (3) and (4) of LODR Regulations.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Listed entities are required to adhere to the RPT Industry Standards to comply with the Master Circular and LODR Regulations regarding RPTs.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Publication of RPT Industry Standards and FAQs
key_clauses.clause_content: The industry associations which are part of ISF (ASSOCHAM, FICCI, and CII) and the stock exchanges shall: 9.1. Publish the RPT Industry Standards on their respective websites. 9.2. Prepare FAQs on RPT Industry Standards in consultation with the SEBI. The FAQs shall take into consideration the queries/clarifications etc. received from the stakeholders. 9.3. Place aforesaid FAQs on their respective websites.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Industry associations and stock exchanges are required to publish the RPT Industry Standards and FAQs on their websites to facilitate understanding and compliance.

documents.summary: This SEBI circular introduces a structured Unified Payment Interface (UPI) address mechanism for SEBI-registered investor-facing intermediaries to collect funds from investors, aiming to enhance accessibility and safety in the securities market. It mandates intermediaries to obtain and make available this structured UPI address, while its use by investors remains optional. The circular details the structure of the UPI address, allocation framework, transaction limits, verification mechanism, responsibilities of various entities, and activity-wise timelines for implementation.

key_clauses.clause_title: Mandatory Adoption of Structured UPI Address by Intermediaries
key_clauses.clause_content: It is mandatory for intermediaries to obtain and make available the structured UPI address to their investors, although the use of this mechanism by investors shall remain optional. Intermediaries are advised and encouraged to actively promote and facilitate the adoption of this mechanism among their investors.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Intermediaries must implement the new UPI structure, incurring costs for system updates and investor education. They must also ensure their systems can handle both old and new UPI IDs during the transition period.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but non-compliance may attract regulatory action from SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: The UPI address will consist of a Username (alphanumeric ID generated for the user followed by an abbreviation representing their intermediary segment) and a handle (@valid combined with the name of the self-certified syndicate banks).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Intermediaries must adhere to the specified naming convention for UPI IDs, ensuring readability and relatability. They need to coordinate with banks to obtain the correct handle.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but incorrect UPI ID structure may lead to transaction failures and regulatory scrutiny.

key_clauses.clause_title: Framework for Allocation and Use of @valid UPI Handles
key_clauses.clause_content: UPI IDs with the handle @valid shall be exclusively designated for payment collection by intermediaries registered with SEBI under merchant category code 6211. The usage of these UPI handles for any activity other than the intended payment collection shall not be permitted. Self-certified syndicate banks shall initiate request to NPCI for the issuance of new UPI handles.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Limits the use of @valid handles to SEBI-registered intermediaries for payment collection only. Banks must follow NPCI guidelines for handle issuance.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Misuse of @valid handles may lead to regulatory action from SEBI and NPCI.

key_clauses.clause_content: The upper limit of up to ₹5 lakhs per day for capital market transactions (done through UPI) shall be available, subject to periodic review and further evaluation as necessary.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Investors are limited to a maximum of ₹5 lakhs per day for UPI transactions in the capital market. This limit may be revised in the future.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Transactions exceeding the limit will be rejected by the UPI system.

key_clauses.clause_title: Mechanism to Verify UPI IDs and Bank Account Details of Intermediaries
key_clauses.clause_content: SEBI is developing a functionality named “SEBI Check” to allow investors to verify the authenticity of UPI IDs either by scanning a QR code or by entering the UPI ID manually. This tool will also include a feature to confirm the bank details such as bank account number and Indian Financial System Code (IFSC) of an intermediary.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Enhances investor protection by providing a tool to verify the legitimacy of intermediaries before making payments.
key_clauses.effective_date: To be announced upon completion of development.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not applicable as this is a verification tool.

documents.summary: This circular outlines the framework for Environment, Social, and Governance (ESG) Debt Securities (excluding green debt securities) in India, including social bonds, sustainability bonds, and sustainability-linked bonds. It specifies definitions, disclosure requirements, responsibilities of issuers, and measures to mitigate the risk of purpose-washing, aiming to facilitate the issuance and listing of these securities.

key_clauses.clause_content: Regulation 2(1)(oa) of the SEBI (Issue and Listing of Non-Convertible Securities) Regulations 2021 defines ESG debt securities as green debt securities, social bonds, sustainability bonds, sustainability-linked bonds, or any other type of bonds issued in accordance with international frameworks adapted to suit Indian requirements as specified by the Board.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies the scope of ESG debt securities, providing a basis for regulatory oversight and compliance.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: Regulation 12A of the SEBI NCS Regulations states that an issuer desirous of issuing and listing ESG Debt Securities shall comply with such conditions as may be specified by the Board.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Establishes the overarching requirement for compliance with SEBI's conditions for issuing and listing ESG debt securities.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: This circular applies to ESG debt securities labelled as ‘social bonds’, ‘sustainability bonds’ and ‘sustainability-linked bonds’ which are listed or proposed to be listed on a recognized stock exchange. The requirements are in addition to the requirements specified in SEBI NCS Regulations and SEBI LODR Regulations.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines the scope of the circular's application, ensuring that issuers of these specific types of ESG debt securities adhere to the specified requirements.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: Debt securities shall be labelled as ‘social bonds’ or ‘sustainability bonds’ or ‘sustainability-linked bonds’ only if the funds raised are proposed to be utilised for financing or refinancing projects and/or assets aligned with ICMA Principles/Guidelines, Climate Bonds Standard, ASEAN Standards, European Union Standards, or any framework or methodology specified by any financial sector regulator in India.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures that the labeling of debt securities accurately reflects the use of funds, preventing misrepresentation and promoting transparency.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: Social Bonds are defined as debt securities issued for raising funds to be utilised for social projects that directly aim to address or mitigate a specific social issue and/or seek to achieve positive social outcomes especially but not exclusively for a target population, falling under specified categories (affordable basic infrastructure, access to essential services, affordable housing, employment generation, food security, socioeconomic advancement).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Provides a clear definition of social bonds, guiding issuers on eligible projects and ensuring that funds are directed towards addressing social issues.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: Sustainability bonds are defined as debt securities issued for raising funds to be utilised for finance or re-finance of a combination of eligible green project(s) and social project(s) as specified under the definition of green bonds and social bonds respectively.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Provides a clear definition of sustainability bonds, guiding issuers on eligible projects and ensuring that funds are directed towards addressing both environmental and social issues.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: Sustainability-linked bonds are defined as debt securities which have their financial and/or structural characteristics linked to predefined sustainability objectives of the Issuer, subject to the condition that such objectives are measured through predefined Sustainability Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and assessed against predefined Sustainability Performance Targets (SPTs).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Provides a clear definition of sustainability-linked bonds, guiding issuers on linking financial characteristics to sustainability performance.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Initial Disclosure Requirements for Social Bonds
key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of social bonds must make specific disclosures in the offer document, including social objectives, decision-making process for project eligibility, tracking of proceeds, details of projects, distribution of proceeds between financing and refinancing, temporary placement of unutilised proceeds, perceived social risks, and details of refinancing.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Enhances transparency and provides investors with comprehensive information about the social impact and financial aspects of social bonds.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Continuous Disclosure Requirements for Social Bonds
key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers who have listed social bonds must provide additional disclosures along with their annual report and financial results, including utilisation of proceeds, details of unutilised proceeds, list of projects, performance indicators, methods and assumptions used, deployment of mitigation plan, and impact reporting. An independent third party reviewer/certifier must be appointed for post-issue management and verification.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures ongoing transparency and accountability in the use of proceeds and the achievement of social impact objectives.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Initial Disclosure Requirements for Sustainability-Linked Bonds
key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of sustainability-linked bonds must make specific disclosures in the offer document, including rationale for issuance, consistency with sustainability strategy, details of KPIs and SPTs, tracking procedures, timelines for target achievement, financial characteristics linked to KPIs, trigger events, fallback mechanisms, potential exceptional events, mitigation plans, and other key factors.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Enhances transparency and provides investors with comprehensive information about the sustainability objectives and financial aspects of sustainability-linked bonds.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Continuous Disclosure Requirements for Sustainability-Linked Bonds
key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers who have listed sustainability-linked bonds must provide additional disclosures along with their annual report and financial results, including up-to-date information on the performance of selected KPIs and a verification report by an independent third-party reviewer outlining the performance against the SPTs and the related impact on the bond’s financial and/or structural characteristics.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures ongoing transparency and accountability in the achievement of sustainability objectives and their impact on the bond's financial characteristics.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of social bonds and sustainability-linked bonds must appoint an independent third-party reviewer/certifier to ascertain alignment with recognized standards, ensure independence and expertise, and specify the scope of the review in the offer document. ESG rating providers registered with SEBI are also eligible to act as third-party reviewers.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Enhances credibility and investor confidence by providing independent verification of the ESG aspects of the debt securities.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of social bonds/sustainability bonds must maintain a decision-making process for determining the continuing eligibility of projects and ensure that all projects funded by the proceeds meet the documented objectives and utilise the proceeds only for the stated purpose.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures that issuers are accountable for the proper use of funds and the achievement of social/sustainability objectives.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers must continuously monitor the social/sustainable impact, avoid utilising funds for ineligible purposes, disclose instances of non-compliance, avoid misleading labels, maintain high standards, quantify negative externalities, and avoid false claims of certification. In case of non-compliance, early redemption of debt securities may be required by majority of debenture holders.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Prevents misuse of funds and ensures that the stated social/sustainability objectives are genuinely pursued.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Early redemption of debt securities

key_clauses.clause_title: Post Listing Obligations for SME Exchange
key_clauses.clause_content: An Issuer who is eligible to list specified securities on SME exchange and intends to issue ESG debt securities shall have to comply with the post listing obligations as specified under ‘Continuous disclosure requirements’ specified in Annexure-A and Annexure-B, and paragraph 2 of Chapter IX (green Debt Securities) of SEBI NCS Master Circular bi-annually.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Specifies the reporting frequency for issuers listed on SME exchange.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_content: Entities having listed non-convertible securities, who have complied with the conditions as specified in MCA general circular No.09/2024 dated September 19, 2024 and have not sent hard copy of statement containing the salient features of all the documents, as specified in Section 136 of Companies Act, 2013 and rules made thereunder, to those holders of non-convertible securities, who have not registered their email address, shall not be subject to any penal action for non-compliance with Regulation 58(1)(b) under the LODR Regulations for the period October 01, 2024 to June 05, 2025.

documents.summary: This circular addresses the issue of accumulation of unsold client securities in brokers' demat accounts after invocation of margin pledged securities. It introduces a combined automated process for invocation and sale of pledged securities, including a 'Pledge release for early pay in' functionality and blocking invoked securities for early pay-in in the client's demat account. The circular also specifies handling of invoked mutual fund units and scenarios where client trading accounts are frozen.

key_clauses.clause_content: Depositories shall provide a functionality of single instruction in the form of ‘Pledge release for early pay in’ to TM/CM wherein pledge will be released and early pay in block will be set up immediately in client demat account subject to pay in validation i.e. only to the extent of delivery obligation of that client as provided by CCs to depositories without the need for physical instruction or electronic instruction or DDPI/POA, in cases where client sells the securities which are pledged in favor of TM/CM as Margin pledged securities (including pledged funded stock) / CUSPA pledge.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Facilitates easier and faster processing of securities sold by clients, reducing operational difficulties for brokers and ensuring timely delivery to the Clearing Corporation.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Invocation and Blocking for Early Pay-in
key_clauses.clause_content: In case of invocation of margin pledged securities (including pledged funded stock) of client by Trading member (TM), the invoked securities, other than mutual fund units that are not traded on the exchanges, shall be blocked for early pay-in in the client’s demat account with a trail being maintained in TM/CM’s ‘Client Securities Margin Pledge Account’ / ‘Client Securities under Margin Funding Account’. The pay in block in client’s demat account shall be subject to pay in validation i.e. only to the extent of delivery obligation of that client as provided by CCs to depositories.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures that invoked securities are readily available for pay-in, preventing delays and potential defaults. It also maintains a clear audit trail of the invocation process.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Invocation and Redemption of Mutual Fund Units
key_clauses.clause_content: In case of invocation of Mutual fund (MF) units that are not traded on the exchange, depositories shall provide a functionality of single instruction in the form of ‘invocation cum redemption’ wherein invoked MF units will come to the TM/CM’s ‘Client Securities Margin Pledge Account’, and go for auto redemption from the said account.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Streamlines the process for redeeming invoked mutual fund units, ensuring that brokers can quickly realize the value of these assets.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Handling Frozen Accounts and 'Not Permitted to Trade' Codes
key_clauses.clause_content: In scenarios, where client’s trading account is frozen or client trading codes are marked as ‘Not permitted to trade’ or equivalent at the stock exchanges subsequent to creation of pledge, the invoked securities will come to demat account of TM/CM and the same shall be sold by TM/CM under the proprietary code. In order to prevent the accumulation of client securities in the demat account of TM/CM, it must be ensured by TM/CM that pay-in of securities is done on the same day of invocation.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Provides a mechanism for brokers to handle invoked securities when client accounts are frozen or trading is restricted, while also preventing the accumulation of client securities in the broker's demat account.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not Specified

documents.summary: This circular modifies the investor charter for Research Analysts to enhance financial consumer protection, financial inclusion, and financial literacy, considering recent developments like the ODR platform and SCORES 2.0. It directs BSE Limited (RAASB) to advise Research Analysts to disseminate the updated Investor Charter to clients and mandates the disclosure of complaint data on their websites and mobile applications.

key_clauses.clause_title: Modification of Investor Charter for Research Analysts
key_clauses.clause_content: The investor charter for Research Analysts is modified to enhance financial consumer protection, financial inclusion, and financial literacy, considering recent developments in the securities market including the introduction of the Online Dispute Resolution (ODR) platform and SCORES 2.0. The updated investor charter is placed at Annexure A.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Research Analysts must adhere to the updated investor charter, impacting their interactions with clients and the information they provide.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Disclosure of Investor Charter to Clients
key_clauses.clause_content: BSE Limited (RAASB) is directed to advise Research Analysts to bring the Investor Charter to the notice of their clients (existing as well as new clients) through disclosing the Investor Charter on their respective websites and mobile applications (if any), making them available at prominent places in the office, provide a copy of Investor Charter as a part of client on-boarding process, through e-mails/ letters etc.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Research Analysts must actively communicate the Investor Charter to their clients through various channels.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified

key_clauses.clause_content: All the Research Analysts shall continue to disclose on their respective websites and mobile applications (if any), the data on complaints received against them or against issues dealt by them and redressal thereof, latest by 7th of succeeding month, as per the format enclosed at Annexure ‘B’ to this circular.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Research Analysts must maintain transparency by disclosing complaint data on their websites and mobile applications.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified

key_clauses.clause_title: Rescinding of Previous Circular and Amendment of Master Circular
key_clauses.clause_content: SEBI Circular No. SEBI/HO/IMD/IMD-II CIS/P/CIR/2021/0685 dated December 13, 2021 stands rescinded and Clause 5 of Master Circular for Research Analysts dated May 21, 2024 stands amended as per this circular.
